title: A Discussion with Nez Perce Jazz Musicians
event: A Discussion with Nez Perce Jazz Musicians
description:
Nez Perce Indian bands played sophisticated jazz in the 1930's and 40's? Wearing eagle feather headdresses and buckskin pants? In fancy white clubs where they sometimes had to eat in the kitchen or leave town as soon as their last set ended? Yes, yes, and yes.

Music has always been a central form of power and identity for Native peoples, and it was challenged and complicated when European newcomers introduced their musical traditions to indigenous North Americans, often through the setting of the compulsory boarding school. Boarding schools emphasized Western music education in specifically in order to "civilize" Indians, yet cross-cultural forms of indigenous musical performance soon began to take shape. The bicultural productions and identities that grew from this musical attempt to "Kill the Indian and Save the Man" are many and diverse.

During this oppressive era of Indian-white relations, Indian musicians found ways to "re-present" American Indian history, culture, and contemporary issues, and to imagine and construct liberatory identities, communities, and nations through a musical performative cultural politics. A musical education that began in U.S. government schools often as martial music such as Sousa marches, was transformed by Indian musicians into one of the most liberatory of all musical genres: jazz. This is an example of Anishinabe (Ojibway) scholar Gerald Vizenor's concept of survivance: survival + resistance and the repudiation of dominance. Learning about Nez Perce Indian jazz performance history helps us understand that tradition is not static, that identities are emergent, and that Native people make things their own in the interest of the continuance of the people and nation.

This presentation will illustrate what results when one spoke in the wheel dominates and oppresses another. But in that oppression there can also arise and be created a new spoke of resistance, in the form of Nez Perce Jazz. It is through this musical expression that Nez Perce musicians found a way to transcend and bridge what can divide and create schisms: speaking in the universal language of music.
bio: Janis Johnson is an Assistant Professor in the English Department, teaching Native American literature and film, African-American literature and ethnic studies. She is also the Acting Coordinator of the American Indian Studies Program, which offers a Minor and an Interdisciplinary Masters degree. Her research on Nez Perce jazz bands (during the early to mid part of the twentieth century) was conducted by Jan in 2007-2009 with Nez Perce tribal members and archival sources. Her research was inspired by the stories Nez Perce friends and acquaintances shared with Jan about their family members' musical careers, and also by Philip Deloria's argument in Indians in Unexpected Places. Deloria maintains that American Indian people took advantage of the opportunities that arose from colonization, participating actively in the making of American modernity and popular culture (2004: 231-32). With two colleagues, Jan is currently working on a critical collection of essays on contemporary Native music (Big Band to Hip Hop), tentatively entitled, Indigenous Pop: Contemporary Native American Music.

title: A Historian Looks at Valentine's Day
event: A Historian Looks at Valentine's Day
description: Valentine's Day is a celebration of romantic love and affection in terms of American culture. This presentation explores how advertising and consumerism have influenced gender roles and romantic love's meaning. The talk highlights the holiday's symbolic elements like flowers and candy, sending a 'valentine's card,' hearts, doves and Cupids. Examines Valentine's Day as both a unique and universal cultural phenomenon and analyzes the holiday's evolution in American culture.
bio: Katherine Aiken is Professor of History at University of Idaho and Dean of College of Letters, Arts and Social Sciences since 2006. She served as History department chair from 2001-2005 and is the recipient of multiple teaching awards. She is the author of books on motherhood, mining history, and Idaho history, and serves as Idaho Humanities Council Chair-elect.
creator: Katherine Aiken
rights: In Copyright - Educational Use Permitted. For more information, please contact University of Idaho Library Special Collections and Archives Department at libspec@uidaho.edu.

title: Adoration of Dora: a Play with Text and Images
event: Adoration of Dora: a Play with Text and Images
description: Set in Paris, 1936, this play explores Surrealist photographer Dora Maar's artistic journey and her relationship with Pablo Picasso. Themes include art, politics, sex and history. The work investigates how artists and lovers inspire and abuse one another and examines the collision of universal and unique worlds. Includes adult themes and content.
bio: Robert Caisley is Associate Professor of Theatre & Film at University of Idaho and Head of Dramatic Writing Program. He has worked as a Creative Consultant for multiple entertainment companies and has extensive speaking experience at numerous universities. He is a playwright with multiple works including 'Happy' and 'The Frybride Queen.' Lauren 'Lojo' Simon is an MFA candidate in dramatic writing at University of Idaho. She is a playwright, journalist, and dramaturg. Her play 'Adoration of Dora' was previously featured at Moxie Theatre's Festival. She has written multiple plays including 'Moscow' and 'Mi Corazon.'
creator: Robert Caisley and Lauren 'Lojo' Simon
rights: In Copyright - Educational Use Permitted. For more information, please contact University of Idaho Library Special Collections and Archives Department at libspec@uidaho.edu.

title: Adventures of time and space travel aboard an amazing machine: The wheel as political metaphor
event: Adventures of time and space travel aboard an amazing machine: The wheel as political metaphor.
description: Used wheel metaphor to explore political and social connections. Hub represents 'us' (individuals, communities, nations), spokes symbolize experiences and connections across generations, and rim represents 'wholeness of being' and collective impacts. Focus on 'life's journeys, incremental destinations, and traveling companions.'
bio: Nancy Chaney was elected Mayor of Moscow in 2005. She has degrees in Nursing and Psychology (Undergraduate, Boise State), Environmental Science (Masters, University of Idaho). Her professional background includes nurse, archaeologist, administrative assistant, small business owner. She is a partner in Veterinary Ophthalmic Specialties, Inc. Married to Gary Bryan, Professor Emeritus from Washington State University, with five stepchildren and ten grandchildren.
creator: Nancy Chaney
rights: In Copyright - Educational Use Permitted. For more information, please contact University of Idaho Library Special Collections and Archives Department at libspec@uidaho.edu.

title: Akwaaba and the Organization of Traditional Music and Dance in Ghanaian Culture
event: Akwaaba and the Organization of Traditional Music and Dance in Ghanaian Culture
description: Explored context of music in Ghanaian society, emphasized participatory nature of performances, focused on 'Akwaaba' (welcome) cultural principle, and demonstrated Ewe Name Dance as example of West African music/dance characteristics. Highlighted elements like call-and-response, bilateral motion, and polyrhythm, and showed connections between dance and spiritual/ritualistic practices.
bio: Barry Bilderback is Assistant professor of music history and ethnomusicology at the Lionel Hampton School of Music. He developed faculty-led study abroad course 'Africa's Calling: Culture in Ghana' and previously taught at Linfield College and University of Oregon. He serves as Vice President of College Music Society/Pacific Northwest Chapter and is researching contemporary Ghanaian music institutions while collaborating with Ghanaian music scholars and cultural leaders.
creator: Barry Bilderback
rights: In Copyright - Educational Use Permitted. For more information, please contact University of Idaho Library Special Collections and Archives Department at libspec@uidaho.edu.
